measures.plotting — Plotting Results into Graphs¶

This module provides helper function to plot graphs constructed from the results of simulations. It uses the matplotlib.pyplot module for all graph creations.

Note that, for the plotting of complex/custom graphs, the generic functions provided in this module may not be flexible enough. However, the code for custom function plotting can be inspired by the code in this module.

exception measures.plotting.PlottingException[source]¶

Bases: Exception

Raised when an error occurs during the formatting of data into a graph

measures.plotting.do_plot_simple_metric(x_values, y_values, stdevs, graph_description, several_curves=None, save_to=None, overwrite_existing=False, color='b', marker='s', marker_size=6, linestyle='-', linewidth=1, legend_placement='upper right', xlim=None, ylim=None)[source]¶

Actually plots a simple metric, producing a bar plot of one or several curves, based on data points.

This function is called by plot_simple_metric(), but provided in a stand-alone mode for a more fine-grained control of its inputs.

Parameters:
  • x_values (list of numbers, or dict) – the values in abscissa. If several_curves is not None, expected to be a dict indexed by the label of the curves, with lists of numbers in values.
  • x_values – the values in ordinate. If several_curves is not None, expected to be a dict indexed by the label of the curves, with lists of numbers in values.
  • several_curves (list of string, optional) – if None, then only one curve is drawn in the graph. If provided as a list of string, draws as many curves as there are strings in the list, using these strings as the curves labels.
  • save_to (string, optional) – path of the folder in which graphs should be saved. If None, the graphs are instead displayed on screen. (Default: None)
  • overwrite_existing (bool, optional) – if graphs are saved and this argument is True, then the new graph may erase existing files. This argument is passed down to save_graphs_simulation_results(). (Default: False)
  • others (color, marker, marker_size, linestyle, linewidth, legend_placement, xlim, ylim) – parameters passed down to the matplotlib.pyplot module. Expected to be simple values when several_curves is None, and list of values otherwise.
measures.plotting.plot_histogram(experiments_results, ordered_measure_params_names, y_stat, print_yerr=False, label_rotation=0, xticks=None, max_bars=None, restrict_to_other_params={}, save_to=None, overwrite_existing=False)[source]¶

Analogous to plot_simple_metric(), but for plotting histograms.

Parameters:
  • experiment_results (dict) – typically, the output of a call to measures.common_measures.generic_measure().
  • ordered_measure_params_names (list of string) – the names of the parameters of the measure. The order of these parameters is preserved, but matters only in case they are displayed to the user (the function does not rely on that order to function).
  • y_stat (tuple) – the statistic to plot (i.e. the metric to plot in ordinate axis). Is processed by a call to process_plot_function_inputs().
  • restrict_to_other_params (dict) – a dict with parameter names as keys, and strings or lists of strings as values. This argument is similat to that of generic_measure(), and allows to include in the graph only results for a certain subset of results.
  • save_to (string, optional) – path of the folder in which graphs should be saved. If None, the graphs are instead displayed on screen. (Default: None)
  • overwrite_existing (bool, optional) – if graphs are saved and this argument is True, then the new graph may erase existing files. This argument is passed down to save_graphs_simulation_results(). (Default: False)
  • print_yerr (bool, optional) – if True, the standard deviation of each bar is printed (Default: False)
  • max_bars (int, optional) – if set to n and the histogram has more than n different x values, the histogram is cut down to n bars. And on the last bar are stacked and accumulatged all the remaining values. This avoids huge and unreadable bar plots.
  • others (label_rotation, xticks) – parameters passed down to the matplotlib.pyplot module.
measures.plotting.plot_simple_metric(experiments_results, ordered_measure_params_names, y_stat, x_param, several_curves=None, restrict_to_other_params={}, save_to=None, overwrite_existing=False)[source]¶

Generic plotting function, producing a bar plot of one or several curves, based on data points.

Produces a graph and saves it as .png file (or disaplys them on screen). This function is designed for plotting simple data; namely, simple curves made of data points. It accepts the results of simulations in arguments, processes these results, and plots them.

Note that this function actually calls do_plot_simple_metric() to plot the graph. Its main purpose is only to process the data from measures and simulations into input acceptable by the latter function.

Parameters:
  • experiment_results (dict) – typically, the output of a call to measures.common_measures.generic_measure().
  • ordered_measure_params_names (list of string) – the names of the parameters of the measure. The order of these parameters is preserved, but matters only in case they are displayed to the user (the function does not rely on that order to function).
  • y_stat (tuple) – the statistic to plot (i.e. the metric to plot in ordinate axis). Is processed by a call to process_plot_function_inputs().
  • x_param (tuple) – the parameter to use in abscissa. Is processed by a call to process_plot_function_inputs(). (Default: None)
  • several_curves (list of string, optional) – if None, then only one curve is drawn in the graph. If provided as a list of string, draws as many curves as there are strings in the list, using these strings as the curves labels.
  • restrict_to_other_params (dict) – a dict with parameter names as keys, and strings or lists of strings as values. This argument is similat to that of generic_measure(), and allows to include in the graph only results for a certain subset of results.
  • save_to (string, optional) – path of the folder in which graphs should be saved. If None, the graphs are instead displayed on screen. (Default: None)
  • overwrite_existing (bool, optional) – if graphs are saved and this argument is True, then the new graph may erase existing files. This argument is passed down to save_graphs_simulation_results(). (Default: False)
measures.plotting.plotfunc(measure_params)[source]¶

Decorator for plotting functions.

Modifies the behavior of a plotting function in the following way. If no ‘x_param’ argument is given to the function, then the function is called on each parameter in measure_params.

Parameters:measure_params (list of string) – the list of the (names of) x_param parameters on which to call the decorated plotting function.
measures.plotting.process_plot_function_inputs(x_param, y_stat, restrict_to_other_params)[source]¶

Checks and pre-processes inputs to a plotting function.

Parameters:
  • x_param (tuple) – a tuple of strings, containing the name of the parameter to put in abscissa of the graph, accompanied with label of the axis, plus optionally a label for the file name
  • y_stat (tuple) – similarl to x_param, but for the ordinate axis
  • restrict_to_other_params (dict) – a dict with parameter names as keys, and strings or lists of strings as values.
Returns:

The processed input parameters
Return type:

(tuple, tuple, list)
